head.title: A Yearlong Battle Against a Condo Sputters to an End

hedline.hl1: A Yearlong Battle Against a Condo Sputters to an End

abstract.p: Update of yearlong battle against construction of 15-story condominium on Brooklyn's Union Street, just steps from Park Slope Historic District; temporary stop work order has been issued until builder issues five-day notification to neighboring property owners (M)

block.p: Last year, people living near Grand Army Plaza learned that a 15-story condominium was planned for Union Street, just steps from the Park Slope Historic District. They quickly rallied against the project, saying it would be a blight in their neighborhood.
For a time, they were successful. But now it appears they have lost their final battle.

Last year, people living near Grand Army Plaza learned that a 15-story condominium was planned for Union Street, just steps from the Park Slope Historic District. They quickly rallied against the project, saying it would be a blight in their neighborhood.
For a time, they were successful. But now it appears they have lost their final battle.

The controversy arose in August 1999, when neighbors noticed that a fence had been erected at 939 Union Street and promptly formed the Grand Army Plaza Coalition to fight the project and others like it.
When excavation on the site began two weeks, coalition members realized that no work permit had been posted. They informed the city's Department of Buildings, which issued a stop-work order.
But the order had been issued in error. The proper permits had, in fact, been filed, according to Paul Wien, a department spokesman.
Then, just as the stop-work order was to be rescinded, department officials realized the developer had not sent the required five-day notification to neighboring property owners.
''Right now, the stop-order stands,'' Mr. Wien said Wednesday. ''But it will be lifted when they send out the five-day notification.''
The coalition is all but conceding defeat.

''Slowly, regrettably, we are realizing that our other options are zero,'' said Marc Zarowin, a coalition spokesman. ''They don't care that 95 percent of the neighborhood is row houses, and this will stand out. They just care about making their money.''
Alex Goldin of the Union Development Group, which is building the project, said the design of the condo would be compatible with the neighborhood's graceful brownstones.

''It will have no impact whatsoever on traffic or parking because it's only 22 families,'' Mr. Goldin said. ''And it will fit right into the landmark environment. It's a good project for the neighborhood, overall, though you'll always have people upset about development.''

NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE -- UPDATE Correction: October 8, 2000, Sunday An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about opposition to a proposed condominium on Union Street in Park Slope, Brooklyn, misspelled the surname of a spokesman for the city's Department of Buildings. He is Paul Wein, not Wien.
